results.title: You've got mail
results.creator_credit: Nora Ephron, Lauren Shuler and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: This story brings romance and courtship (as well as Meg Ryan, Tom Hanks and director Nora Ephron for the third time) into the age of the World Wide Web via email and chat rooms. Joe and Kathleen have a lot in common, they live near each other, they are both in the publishing industry, he in supersized book department stores - Foxbooks, and she in a small independent one - Shop Around the Corner, they even buy coffee at the same place. They have not met in person as yet, but they have met one another in a chat room where they bare their thoughts about life, work and their significant others who are less than perfect. Pretty soon NY152 and Shop Girl want to meet in person, which leads to inevitable angst when two soul mates discover they are business rivals. Cast also includes Parker Posey and Greg Kinnear.

results.title: Starship troopers
results.creator_credit: Paul Verhoeven, Alan Marshall, Jon Davison, Touchstone Pictures and Tri-Star Pictures
results.brief_description: Presented as an enthusiastic, squeaky clean propaganda/soap opera style film, this highly satirical work from director Paul Verhoeven is an effective political comment on militaristic and colonialistic driven societies. Johnny Rico (Casper Van Dien) and his unquestioningly patriotic friends; recent graduates of the Buenos Aires High School, join the Federation forces in a mission to the home planet of an alien bug race that threatens life on earth. What follows is an amazing epic science fiction adventure complete with love triangle, mock news flashes, schlock battle sequences and seamless special effects as the all too mannequin-like characters attempt to overcome their vicious bug enemies. Cast includes Casper Van Dien, Denise Richards, Jake Busey, Neil Patrick Harris, Patrick Muldoon and Michael Ironside. Based on the book by Robert A. Heinlein.

results.title: Alien resurrection
results.creator_credit: Jean-Pierre Jeunet, Bill Badalato, David Giler, Gordon Carroll, Walter Hill and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Sigourney Weaver reprises her role as Ellen Ripley, a big surprise to most fans considering she died at the end of ‘Alien 3’. In this next instalment of the series a group of scientists succeed in resurrecting Ripley by cloning her. Their main motivation being the Queen Alien which lies dormant within her DNA. Science runs amok however when the alien terror is unwittingly unleased on the scientists spacecraft. The newly revived Ripley (who is a different creature in many respects from her past incarnation), must join forces with a group of smugglers and a mysterious young mechanic named Call (Winona Ryder) to combat the vicious aliens. The strength of the alien saga has always been the constantly evolving character of Ripley and the fresh perspective different creative talents have brought to the series. (Ridley Scott directed the first one, James Cameron the second and David Fincher the third). In this fourth instalment, director Jean-Piere Jeunet (‘City of lost children’, ‘Delicatessen’) populates the film with surreal, womb like imagery, plenty of visceral thrills and a magnificent action sequence set underwater. Cast also includes Ron Perlman, Dan Hedaya, Brad Dourif, Michael Wincott and J.E. Freeman.

results.title: Mystic pizza
results.creator_credit: Donald Petrie, Mark Levinson, Scott Rosenfelt and Samuel Goldwyn Company
results.brief_description: Friends Kat, Daisy and Jojo share their insecurities, dreams and aspirations as they work at Mystic Pizza, a successful pizzeria in small town Mystic. Kat (Annabeth Gish) is sensible and intelligent, holding down 4 part time jobs to finance her way through next year’s astronomy course and about to become involved with a married man. Daisy (Julia Roberts in her first major screen role), Kat’s sister, is promiscuous and sexy, arguing with her mother who wants her to “calm down” and involved with rich kid Charlie in a possible rags to riches romance. Jojo (Lili Taylor) is engaged to fishmonger Bill but is suffering from pre-wedding jitters and her healthy libido is at odds with Bill’s catholic conscience. All three of them want to make something of their lives - perhaps get out of Mystic, and all three of them are determined to remain friends forever. Cast also includes William R Moses, Vincent D’Onofrio, Adam Storke and Conchata Ferrell.

results.title: The Lovers = Les amants
results.creator_credit: Louis Malle, Irenee Leriche and Nouvelle Edition Francaise
results.brief_description: Jeanne Moreau plays a bored, rich, provincial married woman (Jeanne) who visits Paris every weekend to escape the boredom of rural Dijon. But even Paris, and her love affair with a polo-playing playboy, cannot make her forget the ennui and tedium of her narrow life. It is only when her car breaks down and she is picked up by the cynical Bernard (Jean-Marc Borc), that Jeanne is forced to revaluate her life and the meanings she has attached to her class and position. Louis Malle’s first feature film created much controversy when released for its matter of fact treatment of adultery and its consequences. An updating of Flaubert’s “Madame Bovary”, it is the hypocrisy and selfishness of the haute-bourgeois that is condemned in “The Lovers”, rather than the sexual freedom desired by both Jeanne and Bernard. This extremely self-assured and accomplished debut is also a loving tribute to the beauty and screen magnetism of Moreau. (Awards: Winner of the Special Jury Prize at the Venice Film Festival) Cast also includes Alain Cuny as Jeanne’s sardonic entrepreneur husband.

results.title: Bright lights, big city
results.creator_credit: James Bridges, Mark Rosenberg, Sydney Pollack and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: When his model wife, Amanda (Phoebe Cates) leaves him, aspiring writer Jamie Conway (Michael J. Fox) plunges into a downward spiral of drugs and alcohol on the Manhattan nightclub scene, ably assisted by his sleazy, yuppie friend Allagash (Kiefer Sutherland). Providing some sort of continuity to dreary days en route to nightly excess is the tabloid story of the plight of a coma baby which parallels Jamie’s fragile existence since his mother died and Amanda left him. With the help of Allagash’s cousin (Michael J. Fox’s wife, Tracy Pollan), a persistent younger brother (Charlie Schlatter), and a well meaning colleague (Swoosie Kurtz), there may be hope for Jamie’s salvation. “Bright lights, big city” is one of Fox’s few attempts to break his comic/Mr Nice Guy persona (“Casualties of war” being another example), and did so to mixed receptions. Based on the book by Jay McInerney.

results.title: The Widow of Saint Pierre = La Veuve de Saint-Pierre [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Patrice Leconte, Frederic Brillion, Gilles Legrand, Cinemaginaire, Epithete Films, France 2 Cinema and France 3 Cinema
results.brief_description: On a remote, desolate French island colony off the coast of Newfoundland, a prisoner (director Emir Kusturica in his onscreen debut), sentenced to death for murder, awaits the arrival of a guillotine from France. In the meantime he is placed under the custody of the Captain of the island’s fortress and military contingent (Daniel Auteuil). Rather than lock him away, the Captain places him in the custodianship of his wife, Madame La (Juliette Binoche) who teaches him how to write and, as their relationship deepens, gradually draws out his best qualities. His transformation from a inarticulate brute into a sensitive, caring man, threatens the authorities who, despite the prisoner’s increasing popularity with the island’s locals, are determined to see “justice” done. Based on an actual incident, “The Widow of Saint-Pierre” reveals how the will of the people can be thwarted by the few in power. As the film progresses, its emotional and political outcomes unfold in increasingly unpredictable directions. The inventive script, alternately serious and comic, combined with the sweeping cinematography and musical score make for a complex, rewarding film. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Of mice and men
results.creator_credit: Gary Sinise, Russ Smith and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: John Malkovich and Gary Sinise both deliver powerhouse performances in this adaptation of John Steinbeck’s classic tale of doomed friendship set in the Great Depression. Best friends Lennie (Malkovich) and George (Sinise) find themselves unemployed and unable to keep stable employment for long, due to Lennie’s infantile mental capacity. Their luck seems to change as they are hired at the Tyler Ranch, although they must endure the over-zealous supervision by the boss’s son, Curley (Casey Siemaszko). After settling in and making friends, their world is torn asunder by tragedy when Curley’s unhappy wife (Sherilyn Fenn) becomes the innocent victim of Lennie’s compassion.

results.title: Jonathan Livingston seagull
results.creator_credit: Hall Bartlett, JLS Partnership and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Richard Bach’s best selling novel about spiritual development and human achievement is brought to life in this rendition, complete with a Neil Diamond soundtrack. The story begins with a flock of seagulls pecking at garbage left by a boat. One of these seagulls - Jonathan (voice supplied by James Franciscus), longs to soar above his current existence, reaching dizzying heights and be the fastest seagull. Thus he leaves the flock to see the world and in search of speed. On reaching aviary heaven he meets Maureen Seagull (voice supplied by Juliet Mills) who introduces Jonathan to new experiences. Jonathan returns to his flock with new found knowledge but the other seagulls are sceptical until he performs a miracle and Jonathan is elevated to a messianic hero. Voices also supplied by Philip Ahn, Richard Crenna, Kelly Harmon and Hal Holbrook.

results.title: The Sweet hereafter
results.creator_credit: Atom Egoyan, Camelia Frieberg, Alliance and Ego Film Arts
results.brief_description: In a small mountain town a lawyer (Ian Holm) arrives to argue that the parents of children killed in a horrific bus accident should claim compensation for the tragedy. The lawyer himself is dealing with his own daughter’s heroin addiction and his inability to assist her. As this wonderful and intelligent film unfolds, we as an audience are led to explore issues of familial and personal responsibility, in particular the difficult searing question of what it means to be parent to a child. We are also asked to question our culture’s increasing fear and terror of accident and death. Filmed in glorious Canadian wilderness in the middle of heavy winter, “The Sweet Hereafter” is a masterful film: script, cinematography and acting are nearly faultless. Egoyan has consistently been proving himself to be one of the most challenging, exciting and experimental of film directors working in cinema since the 1980s. This assured classical film is both a departure and a culmination of his work: his films have all explored the alienation and loneliness of our contemporary world and our increasing estrangement from family and each other. It is no exaggeration to call this film one of the most emotionally and intellectually profound films of modern cinema. Based on a novel by Russell Banks. Cast includes Sarah Polley, Maury Chaykin, Peter Donaldson, Bruce Greenwood and Arsinee Khanjian.
